2.2    Prevention Program

The ammonia refrigeration system at American Cold Storage Foods is considered a ?Program 2? level prevention program as described in Subpart D of 40 CFR 68 (68.65 through 68.87).  While not subject to the Process Safety Management Requirement, certain aspects of the program have been adopted as best practices.

2.2.1    Operating Procedures (40 CFR 68.69)

The Chief Engineer is responsible for:
a.Developing and implementing written operating procedures for the ammonia refrigeration system, including steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations and safety systems and their functions
b.Making operating procedures readily accessible to employees who work in or maintain the ammonia refrigeration system
c.Reviewing operating procedures as often as necessary to assure that they reflect current operating practice, including changes in process chemicals, equipment and technology 
d.Annual certification that operating procedures are current and accurate
e.Developing and implementing safe work practices, such as:
(1)lockout/tagout
(2)confined space entry
(3)opening process equipment or piping

        
2.2.2    Training (40 CFR 68.71)

     The Chief Engineer is responsible for providing initial and refresher training to employees involved with the ammonia refrigeration system and for documenting training records for each affected employee.

Minimum training requirements include:

a.Initial training, with an overview of the process and the operating procedures, with an emphasis on:
(1) Specific safety and health hazards
(2) Emergency operations, including shutdown
(3) Safe work practices

b.Refresher training at least every 3 years

c.Training documentation including employee identification, training date, and means used to verify that employee understood the training

        







2.2.3    Management of Change (40 CFR 68.75)

The Chief Engineer is responsible for:
    a. Establishing and maintaining written procedures for managing changes (in equipment, procedures, or nearby sources) to the ammonia refrigeration system that could affect process safety information, operating procedures, etc.
    b.    Updating other 112(r) program elements that are potentially affected by the change and ensure that affected employees have knowledge of, and are trained in, the changes to the ammonia refrigeration system.


2.2.4    Pre-Startup Review (40 CFR 68.77)

The Maintenance Engineer is responsible for:
    a.    Performing a start-up review when a new or modified source affects the process     safety information for the ammonia refrigeration system
    b.    Informing the Chief Engineer of the proposed modification

    The review shall confirm that:
construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications.
safety and emergency procedures are in place.
training of each employee has occurred.
for new stationary sources, a process hazard analysis has been performed.

    The Warehouse Supervisor will ensure that affected employees are trained in working with the new or modified source.

            
2.2.5    Incident Investigation (40 CFR 68.81)

The Warehouse Supervisor is responsible for assembling a team to investigate incidents that resulted in, or could have resulted in, a release of ammonia from the ammonia refrigeration system, within 48 hours of the incident.  In addition, the Safety Manager will ensure that: 
    a.    a written incident report is prepared (including date of incident, date investigation     began, description of the incident, factors contributing to the incident, and     recommendations).
    b.    every potentially affected employee or contractor reviews the report.
    c.    a system is established to address and resolve the report findings.
    d.    the report is retained for five years.

            
2.2.6    Employee Participation (40 CFR 68.83)

The Warehouse Manager will ensure that affected employees and contractors are consulted in development of the process hazard analysis and that all information regarding the 112(r) program is accessible to these personnel.

            

2.2.7    Hot Work Permit (40 CFR 68.85)

The Maintenance Engineer is responsible for issuing hot work permits when hot work operations are performed on or near the ammonia refrigeration system.  The permit shall document that fire prevention and protection have been implemented prior to beginning hot work operations.  The permit shall be kept on file until after completion of the hot work.

        
2.2.8  Contractors (40 CFR 68.87)

The Warehouse Manager is responsible for:
a.    Providing contractors (that work on, or adjacent to, the ammonia refrigeration system) with information regarding the hazards of the system, emergency response actions, and any other applicable portion of the program, prior to commencement of work.
b.   Developing and implementing safe work practices in covered process areas.
c.   Periodically evaluating the performance of the contractor.2.3  Emergency Response

Responsibility for implementing and maintaining an emergency response program element of the RMP as listed in Subpart E, 40 CFR 68.90 through 68.95 falls to the Safety Manager.  


The Safety Manager is responsible for:

a.Maintaining an emergency response plan.
b.Establishing procedures for use and maintenance of emergency equipment.
c.Training personnel on the use of emergency equipment.
d.Establishing procedures for review and update of the plan.
e.Coordinating elements of the program with the local emergency planning committee.
f.Reviewing the plan during January of each year, via EPAC.

    
2.4  Risk Management Plan

Development of the risk management plan as described in Subpart G, 40 CFR 68.150 through 68.190 is the responsibility of the Safety Manager.  

The Warehouse Supervisor will ensure that: 

a.The RMP is updated at least every 5 years
b.The RMP is updated within 6 months of a change in the ammonia refrigeration system that requires a process hazard analysis or a revised off-site consequence analysis.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Background Data

In accordance with Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations Chapter 68 (40 CFR 68) promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), American Cold Storage submits this Risk Management Plan (RMP) for operations at its Louisville, KY facility.  

American Cold Storage's operations include storing frozen foods and distribution.  American Cold Storage has been in operation at this facility for over 30 years, providing over 20 jobs to the local community.


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy

In this facility, we use Anhydrous Ammonia, which is considered hazardous by the EPA.  This chemical must be used to provide cooling for the storage.  It is our policy to have programs in place dealing with safety precautions for handling these substances and to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to our own health, as well as to reduce the threat to nearby members of the community.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and state rules and regulations.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle ammonia, combined with the safety devices inherent in the design of this facility, as well as the safe handling procedures that we use and the training of our personnel.

American Cold Storage is committed to protecting the health of its employees, the surrounding community, and the environment; therefore, it is American Cold Storage?s policy to maintain compliance with 40 CFR 68 as well as Occupational Safety and Health Organization (OSHA)?s Hazardous Operations and Emergency Response regulations (29 CFR 1910.120). 

Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances

American Cold Storage is not subject to 112(r), of the Clean Air Act, because ammonia, a regulated substance, is not present in any single system, at the facility in amounts greater than 10,000 pounds.  

American Cold Storage is required to maintain low temperatures, which are within standards required by the United St

ates Department of Agriculture (USDA), in the food storage areas of the plant.  American Cold Storage uses anhydrous ammonia (the 112(r) regulated substance) as a refrigerant to maintain the facility within the required range of operating temperatures. American Cold Storage?s refrigeration system, consisting of receivers, compressors, evaporators, condensers, and piping in two systems contains a maximum amount of 17,920 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  The larger of the two systems contains 9,420 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.



Accidental Release Prevention Program

The ammonia refrigeration system is designed and constructed in accordance with ANSI/IIAR 2-1992 Standard for Equipment, Design, and Installation of Ammonia Mechanical Refrigerating Systems.  To prevent and mitigate accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia, American Cold Storage has implemented several precautionary measures.  

American Cold Storage has implemented evaluated and engineered against anhydrous ammonia releases.  Some of the controls installed to prevent catastrophic releases of ammonia are: process equipment (vents, pressure relief valves, backup pumps, and manual shutoffs) and automated controls (electrical distribution system grounding).  In addition, Louisville?s Fire Department HazMat team responds to any ammonia release at the facility.  Seven American Cold Storage personnel are trained to respond to potential ammonia releases (HazMat).

American Cold Storage has developed work order procedures and plans to develop standard operating procedures, which incorporate safety measures into the procedures, for all employees and contractors who have contact with the ammonia refrigeration system.  These safety procedures were developed by the safety team and will be reviewed annually.  American Cold Storage encourages employee participation in development of the control measures used at the plant by means of key employee participation at meetings and an open door policy regarding concerns or sugg

estions.  Any changes to the operating procedures will be communicated to affected employees by following written management of change procedures established by American Cold Storage.

American Cold Storage understands that maintaining the refrigeration system in good working order is essential to preventing accidental releases; therefore, American Cold Storage has implemented a preventative maintenance program.  The preventative maintenance program is scheduled, documented and managed using computer maintenance management to ensure that regular maintenance occurs on the system



Five-Year Accident History

Over the last five years, American Cold Storage experienced one on-site release.

Over the last five years, American Cold Storage has not experienced an accidental off-site release of anhydrous ammonia from the ammonia refrigeration system.



Emergency Response Program 

American Cold Storage has documented emergency response procedures in a document entitled AMERICAN COLD STORAGE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN, to facilitate response efforts in the event of an off-site anhydrous ammonia release.  Included in the response plan are measures to be taken internally by American Cold Storage.

American Cold Storage has trained four (4) on-site personnel to respond to accidental ammonia releases.  University of Louisville provided the last training session in March, 2007 for the following personnel:

Greg Logsdon 
Joe Lile 
Robert Corbin 
Larry Hagen


These personnel are trained in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.120, OSHA?s Hazardous Operations and Emergency Response regulations according to their duties and function.  

To plan for an ammonia release with off-site effects, American Cold Storage includes procedures/equipment to mitigate the release, procedures to inform local response agencies, and procedures for public communication.

In addition to the above local response agencies, American Cold Storage has available emergency response assistance from the Louisville Fire D

epartment, HazMat.  In the event of an anhydrous ammonia release with off-site effects, the general public will be warned using the following methods:

Broadcast message via local media. 
Phone
Door-to-Door                 























Planned Changes to Improve Safety

As a result of American Cold Storage?s initial process hazard analyses, several changes are planned at the facility to improve safety and prevent anhydrous ammonia releases.  These changes are scheduled to be implemented by January 2008 and include:

Walking new employees through the storage facility to point out possible high-risk areas.

Tying the ammonia detectors to the exhaust system.

Providing an automatic shut-off, or a manual shut-off outside the engine room.

Developing written SOPs (to be completed by the end of December, 2008).
